sentence: Salesforce.com (CRM) is set to report second quarter fiscal 2018 earnings results after the closing bell Tuesday.

With CRM stock surging 34% year to date, against an 8% rise for the S&P 500 index, investors are biting their nails and anxious to see if the enterprise cloud computing company can sustain its dominant growth.
For the quarter that ended July, the San Francisco-based company is expected to earn 32 cents per share on revenue on $2.51 billion, translating to year-over-year respective growth of 33% and 23.4%.
For the full year, ending in December, earnings are projected to increase 28.7% year over year to $1.30 per share, while revenue of $10.28 billion would mark a 22.5% rise.
Thanks to its leading position among the cloud, Salesforce stock has been one of the stronger growth stories in the technology sector over the past decade.

As evidenced by the solid revenue growth projections for both the quarter and full year, Salesforce continues to deliver where it matters, though the rate of growth has slowed from prior levels of above 30%.
More recently, revenue has risen by an average of 25% over the past four quarters.

But with shares now trading near all-time high of around $92, Salesforce must justify Wall Street’s optimism by delivering not only a top- and bottom-line beat, but also strong outlook for third quarter and fiscal years.
And the company must do so as competition from, among others, Microsoft (MSFT) and Oracle (ORCL) have grown more fierce.
In that vein, the company’s “bookings” metric (a.k.a “billings”), which denotes the strength of future sales, will be closely watched.
Analysts are modeling for that number to come to $2.17 billion, which is high considering the first quarter number came to $1.89 billion.
Salesforce shares would immediately take off if bookings beat.
Conversely, a big miss and the stock gets punished.

To that end, it’s worth noting here that the third quarter billings is typically weak due to seasonality, which means Salesforce, which guided below analysts’ estimates in the previous two quarters, is likely to guide lower for the next quarter.
But that shouldn’t raise concern, according to Suntrust analyst Terry Tillman.

"We believe the company will report upside to key 2Q18 estimates, and more importantly, the stage is set for strong 2H18 stock performance owing to seasonal strength in billings, event-driven catalysts (Dreamforce conference) as well as growing monetization of a variety of newer cloud products," Tillman wrote in a note on Friday.
In other words, Salesforce’s second half of its current fiscal year may be better than the first half as earnings, revenue and bookings are expected to grow at healthy rates.
And despite increased competition, you would be hard-pressed to find a more consistent revenue producer when it comes to the cloud.
The problem is, the market already knows this.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
